content:
Hello Everyone!
I'm GMing since about two months a Masks game and i want to introduce to the comunity the team. From top to botom right:
Exelion (The Nova) : He is a selfconcius raw energy being from the outer space. Came to earth searching knowledge and after a brew time living with homeless in Argentina, he move to Halcyon city atracted by the superhéroe community there, arrive just in time to join to the team stoping an alien invasion.
Crimson Bastard (The Legacy) : The offspring of a well know Heroine called Crimson Knightress gifted with a godlike Beauty like his mother. He intend to be a Good hero like The golden generation but in between his grandfather (A Late golden generation Mage from another plane of existence called Questalia) and Crimson Knightress battle to model him in to a diferent hero.
Elastro (The Star): Another alien in the team, but this one came from a planet full of shapeshifters. In earth he try to be one of the most famous Hero of the world (or the universe. Why not?) inspired in the Exemplars actual leader, Elastic, who is his mentor. Elastro also is a well know YouTuber with a great audience of teenagers lovers of the powered people. He always is recording the adventures of the team.
Red X (The Bull): A baby stealed from his home and raised by a corporation of ninjas, mad cientist and criminals to create the perfect weapon. After the order was desmantelated, he live a brief period of his life like a teenage criminal until a Heroine "All mighty Girl" take in adoption and teach him how to be a good hero.
They are now the Claw sponsored like by the Exemplars and the Halcyon City Herald to be the vanguard of the new generation of heroes.
*The image was created by Elastro ( +Lucas Eliel Sosa ) from the art of deck of villany and core playbooks.

comments.content: I love how different groups take the game in such different directions. Mine is so much more darkish.
To be fair, Penny Dreadnought thinks of himself as a fairly dark character. He's avenging his parents' death by waging a one-man war on a whole category of currency! ;P
All penny-related crimes cost slightly more to commit than they make.

content:
Here's an NPC superhero folks are welcome to use. He's a mentor to a PC (Halfpenny) in my game.

Name: Penny Dreadnought
Generation: Bronze
Origin: When both of his parents were accidentally killed by a single penny dropped off the top of the Empire State Building, he swore to protect the world from all penny-related crime.
Abilities: Penny Dreadnought has become a master pugilist, wearing penny-themed brass-knuckles.
Demeanor: Penny Dreadnought is intensely serious about defeating penny-related crime, speaking in a growly voice even when he makes coin-based puns. ("Let me throw in my two cents." punch, punch!)
Other Resources: Penny Dreadnought has a secret base ("The Penny-tentiary") and rides a motorized penny farthing bicycle.

comments.content: What you think about a meta reference and calling it " Masks"?? :D
I liked the name. Otherwise: "UnMasked", "Hot As Lazers".
Tytans’ Tower. (Spelling changed to avoid copyright infringement.)
Big thumbs-up for "Unmasked"
Uuhhhhh, i think we have a winner!

Could be a comic onomapoteia too like "Thwack!" or "Pow!"
Unmask is good though.
Unmasked also fits into this sleazy sexualisation of celebrity minors.
High-Fliers!
Behind the Mask

High-Fliers is probably more adult, it's the Bloomberg of the superhero world. Unmasked is the teen gossip one.

Same publishing company, ofc.
Empowered
Now I want a game about running a teen magazine for young supers...
you use Kingdom for that, right?
+Marshall Miller it's easy. Nobody can really consistently interview heroes unless he's somehow powered himself.
+Gustavo Campanelli tell that to Lois and Iris!

Unmasked seems to be the clear winner, but if you need a few more for spice, here you go. (As a fair warning, I haven't read a teen magazine in decades, so it's possible I'm super far off!)

Capes (or maybe just Cape) is your fashion mag for and about supers. Most of what's in there is highlighting civilian outfits of known heroes, critiquing what new heroes are wearing, or tips on how to dress "hero chic". Teen Capes is probably exactly what you'd expect, but they'd also occasionally have life-saving tips for those who want to become heroes themselves.

Watchmen is more heavily focused on "keeping the public informed". What this means in practice is a lot of rumors about what villains are secretly plotting, and how heroes are secretly plotting against you. Watchmen's a more conservative-leaning magazine than most - don't expect to get a fair shake, especially if you're not a straight, white cis man. It used to be a reputable source, decades ago, but it's fallen far.

Finally, there's Bad Boys. Imagine the sort of adoration and devotion that gets lauded on Justin Beiber, One Direction, and those sorts of teen heartthrobs. Only instead of pop stars, it focuses on, well, "bad boys" - which ranges from delinquent young heroes to dangerous but popular supervillains. The heroes of your game may or may not feature in there - but it's safe to assume that the less they want to be in there, the more likely they will be (and vice versa).

SuperBeat
Powerzine
MEGA!
We called ours Haly.
Teen Writins
Superb.

content:
Help me find a name for a teen magazine

So our game has a teen magazine that is interested in our heroes. Think Teen Vogue meets celebrity rumors but about superheroes. A bit of lifestyle, a bit of gossip and some fashion. WiP name is CapeLyf3 but I am sure there are better options, right?

comments.content: SWAT and TASER are a pair of sanctioned heroes that work with the metro police.  SWAT's keen senses and tactical skills were legendary.  While she wasn't a power house, everything and everyone was a tool in her arsenal.  In another country, she might have been called a ninja.  TASER never quite filled out the tactical vest he wore, but his non-lethal electrical powers made him an asset versus humans and robots.  And, his electro-sense doubled as a great bloodhound for any perp dumb enough to carry a cell phone or other device.

Due to a lack of detail, I'm Assuming these are NPCs for a Rival Team to the PCs(I.E. More experienced than the PCs, despite being their peers, Very High and mighty), If they are part of the Same team as the PCs I would suggest some nerfing, and personality overhauls. If they are adults then some age adjustment should be all that is necessary...

Anyway here is one I came up with:

Strategem - Team Leader - Abilities: Physical Perfection, Perfect Memory - Bio: Annabelle Ferris(16) Has trained her body to the limit of what a normal human is capable of since she was young, This combined with her incredible memory makes he one of the most formidable heroes to exist despite her age. In combat, she can perfectly mimic an opponent's fighting style after just seeing them do something once, so long as they are doing so with physical talent or a weapon. She is also excellent when it comes to situations that require problem-solving in hero work as she has memorized every case file she has access to and read every book of conventional strategy.
Weaknesses: Creative Thinking-Annabelle has come to rely on her memory as a crutch, and never bothered to learn actual problem-solving as her memory mimics this but even better, if she encounters a situation where she has little to no prior context then she will hit a mental blank and be entirely unsure of what to do,

Arrogance-Due to her commonly undisturbed record of success, Anabelle cannot cope with failure, and will never admit if she isn't the smartest person, and will often even act as though she knows exactly what to do even if she is clueless. She never asks for help with ideas and takes even a suggestion that someone MIGHT know more than her as a personal attack.
I'll have so much fun...

Dice is the Team Leader, though he really wishes he weren't. He's risen through the ranks by having a history of high profile successes against villains, and most people think he wins these fights through clever and unpredictable use of telekinetic abilities.

The truth is, his real superpower is being blessed and cursed with extreme luck. He finds himself facing danger purely by chance, and wins the day through no fault of his own. It's terrifying to live through, but he knows it would be worse if he ever told anyone the truth. Because as everyone knows, if you point out your luck you immediately lose it, and if all he was left with was the downswing of his powers he wouldn't last a week.

LASERFACE mainly became a cop for the health and dental, figuring it would be an easy gig in a city brimming with superheroes to do all the real work. But when she took advantage of the free health insurance to have her vision corrected, there was an accident that overloaded the surgical laser, bombarding her optic nerves with strange and exotic energies.

Ever since then, she's been able to emit electromagnetic waves of any frequency from her eyes. With high intensity light, she can burn through steel. With x-rays, she can see through walls. With radio, she can jam comms. With microwave and infrared emissions, she can cook popcorn and change the channel without leaving the sofa. Mostly the team gets use out of the first three.
Are you on Maskbook? Shield Maiden is my go-to police super.

comments.content:
I found the "you are not killers" rule in Masks very refreshing on account of all the grim grim dark grim that I otherwise imbibe on a daily basis. Players have had to come up with some creative solutions now and again, and give their characters some very humanizing characterization, because of the enforcement of this rule.

In a fairly long running campaign, we've had one killing. Our Protege used a Moment of Truth to take a handgun off of our not!Joker to shoot an unconscious not!Scarecrow, thereby preventing the doomsday machine that would've amplified and projected his fear powers across the whole city from unleashing its apocalyptic wave of havoc.

This changed everything. It made him feared by heroes and villains alike. It made his mentor, not!Batman, go on a crusade to see him imprisoned on murder charges and, failing that, turn the entire superhero community of Halcyon City against him. It ruined his life, changed his playbook, and set up a massive character growth arc involving the entire team that has yet to culminate.

This was one death. It was a big deal! I know it's unrealistic, but treating human life with this kind of value and gravity has been really entertaining, and hella dramatic.

+Jim Crocker I don't want to defend Marvel Comics, of course, however the "young killer teen used as a simple tool" is a cliché that I suppose exists from... Ever. With the (usual) redemption / grow arc, that bring the machine-teen to understand the world, and gain human feelings. Great space for epic, struggling stories, in it.
+Jim Crocker This is from a very old comic though. But, you're free to do what you like.
Written in the 21st century =/= "very old".

^ That's a matter of perspective. 11 years ago is about 44%* of my time alive so to me it's "very old".

Edit: Did the actual math.
(I suppose you meant to quote Benjamin)
+Andrea Parducci oops, yeah. Sorry.

You guys are so fixated on the "very old" part of that statement. I obviously didn't meant it to be from sometime like the 30's or the 60's, if I did I would have mentioned those decades.
In anycase, it has been relevant to the Masks games I've been apart of. I've seen players who ignore the "You are not killers" part of the rule book. Those games quickly die of course. And, yes, this run didn't lean heavily on the teen drama like the creative team before it but Masks can, and often, end up in situations depicted in the run.

I would argue that Masks stakes its territory in a particular corner of the genre and this isn't it. But in larger geek media, this concept--the killing machine that needs to be reigned in--sees a lot of play. Two that come to mind are Terminator 2 ("They'll Live") and the recent Lost in Space TV series. I would totally RP those moments. But probably not in Masks with a PC. (I would totally do it with an NPC the PC has influence over and has to control.)

I guess I'm bit more liberal when it comes to which fits in with the Masks territory. But, yeah, I totally see what you're getting at.

This post is more of a jab at the problem players I've encountered while playing Masks.
This isn't MASKS but X-23 kills people... So both ideas are right to me

content:
#halcyonian


Playbook: Beacon
Hero Name: The Emerald Errant
Real Name: Katya Yazzie

Look: Female, Indigenous & Russian parentage, built like a brick wall and almost as tall, face made for smiling, comfortable clothing, with an Iconic Costume (full plate armor is pretty recognizable)

Abilities: Martial Arts (in the vein of the Armored Combat League), Hammers (instead of Swords)

Labels: Put the +1 into Savior
Danger: -1
Freak: -1
Savior: +3
Superior: 0
Mundane: +2

Beacon Moves:
-Won't Let You Down
-Suck it, Domitian

Backstory:
-How did you first gain your skills?
Practice and training. Katya had always been fascinated with the Golden Age heroes and wanted to emulate them. It wasn't until she stumbled across the armor of the Golden Age hero known as the Grey Gallant that she found the means to fulfill her dream.

-When did you first put on your costume?
After repairing the armor (Grey Gallant had met a grizzly end) and painting it a bright emerald green, Katya started walking a beat in search of injustice.

-Who, outside the team, thinks you shouldn't be a superhero?
Her grandmother would rather she focus on her schoolwork or other, local, means of helping the community (instead of playing at being a knight and causing more harm than good).

-Why do you try to be a hero?
For Katya, it's fun first and consequences later. She also is in love with the idea of being a close-to-home hero, someone who spends their time helping the community thrive, instead of always focusing on world ending threats. Much like the Golden Age heroes she emulates, she thinks small picture, not large.

-Why do you care about the team?
"Together, we are strong." It also helps that she mother hens the younger heroes. She is all heart.

Drives:
-Lead the team successfully into battle.
-Help a teammate when they need you most.
-Save a teammate's life.
-Stop a fight with calm words.

Katya as a hero is very much inspired by Overwatch's Reinhardt (but w/o the power armor and rocket hammer, natch) and my own love of my grandparents and the stories of their lives.
As a character, she is very much big hearted. A caring person who wants to help others as much as she can, mixed with a loud, boisterous personality.
Plus I liked the idea of a Modern hero who wasn't inspired by Bronze or Silver -agers.

Hope you have fun! I sure am!

Give me your villains!

Specifically, I'm looking for some good examples for villain moves. You've got villain move examples from your game? Let's see 'em!

Villain: Technosaurus Rex

What appears to be a robot or exoskeleton Allosaurus is tearing appart the city; stomping on cars and people alike.

Technosaurus Rex - Silver Generation
Drive: To bring back Dinosaurs, elevate them to sentience and have them rule this earth once again

Moves:
* Distract them with Raptorbots (size of a turkey, not a lion)
* Directly ram through an obstacle
* Tear apart with massive jaws
* Reveal some tech that covers up an apparent weakness

Conditions:
* Angry
* Hopeless
* Guilty

Hero Name: Pipeline
Playbook: The Transformed
Real Name: Thomas Caballero
Look: Hispanic teenage boy with body made entirely of transparent water.
Abilities: Transmuting Flesh and Hydrokinesis
Labels - After the end of the last session.
Freak +2
Danger +1
Savior +2
Superior 0
Mundane -2
Transformed Moves
I am not my body
Unstoppable - Things get broken and very wet.
Wish I could be
Backstory
Thomas Ignacio Caballero is a mutant. His father, Diego, worked on a research project at Atomo Labs. The project involved dangerous isotopes that would hopefully be used to produce efficient nucleardriven engines. Unknown to Thomas’ father, these isotopes would cause his son to be a mutant, and cause his early death.

Diego died when Thomas was only 12 years old. Thomas could not handle his father’s death, and started to rebel. He took in with several street gangs as way to get out of the house. At the age of 14, Thomas’ mutant powers started to manifest themselves. At first, Thomas would wake up soaking wet. Soon, he noticed that his skin was becoming clear, and that he quickly became dehydrated. The other members of his gang turned against Thomas, and threw him out when they saw his skin changing. In a fit of rage, Thomas sent the gang leader 30 feet in the air with a jet of high-pressure water! Thomas had nowhere to turn, so he returned home.

Thomas’ mother, Maria, took in her son, and has gained back his respect and love. The two have made a pact that they will do anything in their power to make sure these strange mutant powers do not prevent Thomas from making a normal life for himself. Thomas is currently a model student at Halcyon High School, and plans to take the accelerated placement exam for Chemistry and Computer Science.

content:
#halcyonian

Here's the Outsider from the Weekday Warriors group, current as of the official wind-down of play last month because real life and holidaze.

Random (so-called because even SHE didn't know what the next gizmo pulled out of her bag of tricks would do) was not the most serious of the group, but she had some surprising depths. She was also, thanks to the impressive weapons suite on her Yacht, probably the single most destructive member of the party in a collateral sense, although our Legacy gave her a good run for the money.

If I had the time to do this game over again, I'd have emphasized her grease-monkey love affair with primitive Earth-tech a lot more than I was able to. This is an Imperial Princess who would rather be down in the motor pool with a spanner and some lug nuts.
